page.title: 14Bredwardine; Wildlife I
page.content: The fields in the area are relatively small and hedgerows have largely been preserved by the farmers. There are plenty of areas of undisturbed habitat for wildlife, including coppices, small groups of neglected trees, patches of bramble and gorse and overgrown disused pathways. The owner of a stretch of woodland on Bredwardine Hill keeps it undisturbed as a sanctury for wild creatures. There are ponds, reed beds, and marshy areas alongside the river, and some small streams down the hillsides. Thw high-banked lanes are covered with a profusion of wild flowers in Spring and Summer and there are berries and nuts galore in the Autumn. Lists of the less common species of birds, flowers and animals often observed here are given on Page 15.
